Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Expectation2: Follow safety protocols to prevent accidents and injuries on site
Situation2: Before starting structural work, the carpenter needs to inspect and maintain tools and equipment to ensure safety and efficiency
Story: My phone buzzed again, vibrating insistently in my pocket as I knelt beside the workbench. I knew it was Mom—she always texted around this time, wanting to know how my day was going, if I’d eaten, if I was warm enough in the workshop. I usually replied right away, sending her a quick photo or a voice note, just to keep her from worrying. But today, I was behind schedule. The circular saw needed a thorough inspection before I could start cutting the new beams, and the foreman had reminded us—no shortcuts, no distractions. Safety first, always. I could almost hear his voice in my head, stern and unyielding. My hands hovered over my phone, torn. If I answered Mom now, I’d be breaking protocol, risking a lapse in focus. If I ignored her, she’d worry, maybe even call, and I’d feel that familiar guilt gnawing at me. The saw gleamed under the harsh light, waiting. My phone buzzed again. I stood there, caught between the expectations of a caring daughter and a responsible carpenter, my heart pounding with the weight of both.
